comment.text:
Works for me: 1 desktop & 2 laptops all using the Mate Desktop Environment.

sirius: desktop 16GB Intel i7-3770 CPU -- real:10m2.380s user:4m36.831s sys:4m48.276s

sedna: laptop 8GB Intel i5-2520M CPU Lenovo T420 -- real:9m4.268s user:3m45.730s sys:4m33.048s

mercury: laptop 32GB AMD Ryzen 7 5700U with Radeon Graphics -- real:14m23.069s user:6m45.132s sys:5m34.944s

It is curious that sedna (an old slow CPU) runs the performances tests significantly faster than mercury (a modern faster CPU)!

Works for me, it's been up for a couple of hours now with no issues noticed.  
The regression tests pass OK. AMD 965, x86_64 work station, SSD's > RAID1. Plasma DE from Zawertun's COPR.  Running X-org, nVidia GT 1030 using nVidia RPM's from RPMFusion (470.74)

Passed the regression tests. Acer Aspire V3-571 v: V2.11 Processors: 8 × Intel® Core™ i7-3632QM CPU @ 2.20GHz Memory: 15.4 GiB of RAM Graphics Processor: Mesa Intel® HD Graphics 4000.
Will test further to see if suspension works. But for now, is mostly doing fine.

Looks ok for me. Runs since it was ready in koji. Works on baremetal (non UEFI mode) AMD Ryzen5 3600, Mainboard MSI B450M Mortar Max with prop. nvidia driver from rpmfusion.org (GTX980 card). Works with Gnome-Desktop (Xorg). Regression test passed (paxtest, selinux-dac-controls and libhugetlbfs skipped).
Default & performance tests pass (KVM)
Default & performance tests pass (KVM)
Default & performance tests pass (KVM)
i7-9700K(UHD Graphics 630): kernel regression test passed. Works fine for daily use.

On my old laptop with Intel Core 2 Duo T6570 with Nvidia GeForce 310M with kernel regression test I found a warn on `./default/sysfs-perms`.

After read the logs file it said found a writable file `fixed_rate_idx`. Then I change the permission of file mentioned to read only and run the test again. Now all are `passed`.

But I don't know what actually the different between make file `fixed_rate_idx` writeable or read only on the system.
Anyone able to test https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2021-854826abc1 on F34 please?

bugs.title: CVE-2021-3760 kernel: nfc: Use-After-Free vulnerability of ndev->rf_conn_info object

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2021-3760 kernel: nfc: Use-After-Free vulnerability of ndev->rf_conn_info object

long_desc.thetext: A flaw was found in the Linux kernel in NFC stack (protocol) that is UAF vulnerability of ndev->rf_conn_info object.

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2017943]

This bug is now closed. Further updates for individual products will be reflected on the CVE page(s):

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2021-3760

bugs.title: CVE-2021-43056 kernel: ppc: kvm: allows a malicious KVM guest to crash the host

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2021-43056 kernel: ppc: kvm: allows a malicious KVM guest to crash the host

long_desc.thetext:
A denial of service problem was found in KVM specific to powerpc. In this flaw, a user with local access can confuse the host offline code, causing the guest to crash.

References:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=cdeb5d7d890e14f3b70e8087e745c4a6a7d9f337

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2017074]

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2022:1988 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2022:1988

This bug is now closed. Further updates for individual products will be reflected on the CVE page(s):

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2021-43056

bugs.title: CVE-2021-43056 kernel: ppc: kvm: allows a malicious KVM guest to crash the host [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2021-43056 kernel: ppc: kvm: allows a malicious KVM guest to crash the host [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2021-43056 kernel: ppc: kvm: allows a malicious KVM guest to crash the host

long_desc.thetext:
A denial of service problem was found in KVM specific to powerpc. In this flaw, a user with local access can confuse the host offline code, causing the guest to crash.

References:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=cdeb5d7d890e14f3b70e8087e745c4a6a7d9f337

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2017074]

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2022:1988 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2022:1988

This bug is now closed. Further updates for individual products will be reflected on the CVE page(s):

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2021-43056

This is an automatically created tracking bug!  It was created to ensure
that one or more security vulnerabilities are fixed in affected versions
of fedora-all.

For comments that are specific to the vulnerability please use bugs filed
against the "Security Response" product referenced in the "Blocks" field.

For more information see:
http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Security/TrackingBugs

When submitting as an update, use the fedpkg template provided in the next
comment(s).  This will include the bug IDs of this tracking bug as well as
the relevant top-level CVE bugs.

Please also mention the CVE IDs being fixed in the RPM changelog and the
fedpkg commit message.

NOTE: this issue affects multiple supported versions of Fedora. While only
one tracking bug has been filed, please correct all affected versions at
the same time.  If you need to fix the versions independent of each other,
you may clone this bug as appropriate.

Reproducers, if any, will remain confidential and never be made public, unless done so by the security team.

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# low, medium, high, urgent (required)
severity=medium

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876
bugs=2017073,2017074

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for [PUT CVEs HERE]

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

Additionally, you may opt to use the bodhi web interface to submit updates:

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/new

comments.text:
Works fine. Default and performance regression tests also pass on all my systems:

- Ryzen 5800X on ASUS ROG X570-E with NVidia GTX 1070 running rpmfusion drivers
- dell XPS 13 9370 (Intel Core i7 8550U / UHD Graphics 620)

comments.text:
On my old laptop with Intel Core 2 Duo T6570 with Nvidia GeForce 310M with kernel regression test I found a warn on `./default/sysfs-perms`.

After read the logs file it said found a writable file `fixed_rate_idx`. Then I change the permission of file mentioned to read only and run the test again. Now all are `passed`.

But I don't know what actually the different between make file `fixed_rate_idx` writeable or read only on the system.
This update has been submitted for stable by jforbes.
This update has been pushed to stable.

notes: The 5.14.15 stable kernel update contains a number of important fixes across the tree.
title: kernel-5.14.15-300.fc35
